article.description: Trojans sweep Bruins for first time since 1992
article.headline: Trojans sweep Bruins for first time since 1992
article.linkText: Trojans sweep Bruins for first time since 1992
article.story: LOS ANGELES (AP) -- Errick Craven instinctively wanted to whoop it up when Southern California led UCLA by 10 points in the second half. But he stayed calm, and his poise at the foul line helped the Trojans complete a sweep of their crosstown rivals for the first time since 1992. Craven converted two free throws with 4.4 seconds remaining to give USC an 86-85 victory over UCLA, which extended its losing streak to nine games Wednesday night. "I tried to stay calm, but it was hard,'' Craven said. "I shoot hundreds of free throws in practice and I just told myself I was going to knock them down. Jason Kapono tried to say something. I just blocked it out.'' Jon Crispin took an inbounds pass from Kapono and tossed up an off-balance 3-pointer that hit the glass to the left of the basket as time expired, keeping the Bruins mired in their worst losing skid since 1940-41 when they lost 10 in a row. "I had plenty of time on the clock. It was stupid. I could have tried to get fouled, pump faked or just gone straight up and I would've gotten a good look at it,'' Crispin said. "These guys expect me to make whatever I take. I expect the same from myself. From a freshman, it's one thing, but this is my fourth year in college. I should have been able to get a better shot than that.'' USC fans broke into a derogatory chant as the Bruins filed off the Los Angeles Sports Arena court. The Trojans have won three of their last four against the Bruins and for the first time since 1940-41, USC has swept UCLA in football and men's basketball. "It's close, but we still were down by 10,'' Kapono said. "It just came down to getting some stops on the defensive end. Craven just kept hitting crazy runners. They made some tough shots, but we also didn't prevent them from getting in the lane.'' Desmon Farmer scored 28 points, including nine straight in the final 3:47, for the Trojans (9-9, 5-5 Pac-10). Craven added 19 points, Rory O'Neil had 12 points, Craven's twin brother, Derrick, had 11, and Roydell Smiley added 10. "It was a crapshoot,'' USC coach Henry Bibby said. "Errick didn't shoot free throws well in today's shootaround, but he told me before the game that he was going to get me the game. I'm happy he made those.'' The Trojans were responsible for launching UCLA's losing streak, which began when the Bruins lost 80-75 in the first matchup Jan. 8 at Pauley Pavilion. "You'd think that with the adversity they've been through, they'd be down,'' Bibby said of his alma mater where he won three national championships under John Wooden. "But they came here to win. They have nothing to hang their heads about. We got some breaks at the end.'' Dijon Thompson scored a career-high 25 points for UCLA (4-13), which remained in ninth place in the Pac-10 at 2-8. Kapono and Ray Young, the team's only seniors, added 12 points each. "It's really frustrating right now,'' forward Andre Patterson said. "We have to learn how to win these games. We keep beating ourselves.'' The loss put the Bruins in greater danger of failing to qualify for the conference tournament, which takes the top eight teams. More significantly, the Bruins will have to win their final nine regular-season games as well as the Pac-10 tournament to assure the school of its 55th consecutive winning season. "The kids played hard, but we weren't rewarded for playing hard,'' UCLA coach Steve Lavin said. "I thought we made some progress, but obviously we came up short. I don't think you can put your finger on one thing. When you're having a season like this, it's a multitude.'' Both teams came into the rivalry game with losing records for the first time since 1988, but each side was emotionally charged throughout. The Bruins rallied to erase a 10-point deficit with eight minutes left, and they led by three points with 58 seconds to go. "We've got to make our own breaks. I need to hit a big shot at the end, that's how we get our breaks,'' Crispin said. "Once it starts going our way, I think we're going to flow and we're going to be fine.'' Neither team led by more than one point for much of the final 3:47. Like Farmer, Thompson was the go-to player for his team, scoring eight of UCLA's final 10 points. USC built its first major lead of the game, 57-48, with an 8-0 run, including six points by Errick Craven, who split defenders for a layup that capped the spurt. Derrick Craven hit a 3-pointer, made a free throw and Farmer added a 3-pointer as the Trojans led 66-56 with 8:14 left. The Bruins used 3-pointers by Crispin, Ryan Walcott and Kapono, along with key blocks on Errick Craven, to cut their deficit to 71-70 with 5:04 remaining. UCLA took only its second lead of the half, 75-73, on another 3-pointer by Walcott before Farmer hit a 3-pointer to make it a one-point game. The teams traded baskets until Thompson scored and got fouled seconds later, making both free throws for an 85-82 lead with 58 seconds left. Derrick Craven scored to draw the Trojans within one. T.J. Cummings missed as the shot clock expired and then Walcott fouled Errick Craven, who made both to give USC an 86-85 lead with 4.4 seconds left. The Trojans called two consecutive timeouts before Kapono inbounded the ball to Crispin, who dribbled to the top of the key and let a 3-pointer fly. "It's disappointing I let the team down like that,'' Crispin said. "If I get another chance at it, I promise you I'll make the next one.'' UCLA led 36-34 at halftime. The Trojans shot only 34 percent in the first half and were outscored 20-10 in the paint. UCLA's Cedric Bozeman sprained his right shoulder at 3:33 of the first half. He returned to start the second half, but wasn't a factor.
